column113: it is easier to do and can pose challenging for inexperienced users
column114: sometimes it could be dragging to do

column113: I liked the overall process of card counting and solving the puzzle
column114: I don't like that the authentication does not use anything that I personally know as in everyone could do the card counting authentication if they are fast enough
column115: During authentication for medium, I miscounted the cards but that was my own issue. Overall, there were no difficulties.
column116: Maybe if the user gets to choose the rules during creation of the MFA? So that only the user knows the ruleset during authentication
column127: I enjoyed the card counting game and wish I was better at chess

column43: It will help me improve my chess level while making my account safer at the same time. It's like gamifying security.
column44: The colour that was next to move was not very clear.
column45: Using a mouse pad to drag and drop was a bit uncomfortable.
column46: I would need to get better at chess!

column113: It was a fun game that I enjoyed playing. I felt like the security was based on my skill, with was interesting.
column114: I am unsure if I would use it to secure sensitive information, but with a password and as a MFA possibly. I would be worried if I was feeling ill and couldn't manage to do it as fast as normally.
column116: I think it would be better to provide the user with more personable action, they set their own difficulty, like number of cards instead of set difficulties.
column127: The system itself is easy to use, but the task itself takes some time to learn.

column78: I liked the gamification of it, and it adds security to it since the hacker would have to complete 3 anagrams within the time contraints which even i found hard
column79: i could only do the easy ones, but that just shows how secure this method is
column80: no technical difficulties, but i could only do the easy ones. this could be because it is not individualised towards my needs
column81: i think it is all good
column127: i think i would need to learn things because i'm not that good at anagrams or chess, but it does feel secure because of that

column78: I dont need to get my phone out (i.e. current 2fa)
column79: it just doesn't feel secure - anyone could solve anagrams.
column80: the anagrams were sometimes too hard.

column78: The anagrams got quite challenging in the harder mode so I felt quite accomplished when I managed to get them right
column79: It was quite stressful when it came to the actual test
column80: In easy mode there were a few cases where there were multiple possible words that could be formed from the given letters and so even if the submitted word is a valid word, the guess could still be wrong
column81: I think one anagram, especially if it's a harder one would be enough in a real life scenario. Also it would be useful if every time I used this authentication method the system learns what my completion pattern is like
column127: I think the letters for the anagram should be visually more distinct than the rest of the text (either different colour, or different font, or both) and maybe add some space between the characters

column78: It was very enjoyable to use. I felt myself get better at solving anagrams the more I used it.
column79: The hard difficulty ones felt impossible.
column81: Maybe only get one correct instead of 3
